results.title: Wait until dark
results.creator_credit: Terence Young, Mel Ferrer and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Susy is an independent and resourceful housewife learning to cope with her blindness resulted from a recent accident. Susy’s life changes drastically when she is terrorised by a group of criminals who believe she is in possession of a doll used by them to smuggle drugs into the country. Alone and cut off from the world outside, Susy must fight for her life against this group of ruthless criminals. Music by Henry Mancini. Cast includes: Audrey Hepburn, Alan Arkin, Richard Crenna, Eferm Zimbalist Jr. and Jack Weston.

results.title: I can jump puddles. Ep. 1
results.creator_credit: Kevin Dobson, John Gauci and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: A 9 part television serial about Australian author Alan Marshall, from his childhood and his diagnosis with Polio to his adulthood as he struggles to become a writer. Based on his three autobiographical novels “I can Jump Puddles”, ‘This is the Grass” and “How Beautiful are thy Feet”. Growing up in rural Western Victoria, young Alan Marshall loves running, writing and horses. When Alan is diagnosed with Polio and becomes bedridden, his family do all they can to help him, including straightening his legs with force. When 3 months of home treatment makes no change to his condition, Alan is sent to hospital, to have his legs operated on. While there, Alan’s friendly nature and good spirits quickly capture the love of the nurses and the camaraderie of the men in the ward.

results.title: I can jump puddles. Ep. 2
results.creator_credit: Kevin Dobson, John Gauci and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: A 9 part television serial about Australian author Alan Marshall, from his childhood and his diagnosis with Polio to his adulthood as he struggles to become a writer. Based on his three autobiographical novels “I can Jump Puddles”, ‘This is the Grass” and “How Beautiful are thy Feet”. Following his operation, Alan is in extreme pain, although at first his anguish is dismissed by the nurses. The doctor prescribes sunshine as medicine and Alan ventures into the world for the first time in months. Quickly learning to get himself around on his crutches, Alan goes home, and despite being pushed around in a modified pram, returns to school, and falls in love with Maggie Mulligan. When he is challenged to a fight by another classmate, and wins, Alan earns the respect of his classmates.

results.title: I can jump puddles. Ep. 3
results.creator_credit: Kevin Dobson, John Gauci and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: A 9 part television serial about Australian author Alan Marshall, from his childhood and his diagnosis with Polio to his adulthood as he struggles to become a writer. Based on his three autobiographical novels “I can Jump Puddles”, ‘This is the Grass” and “How Beautiful are thy Feet”. Alan is determined to ride his pony Katie again, however his father forbids it, as he says there is too great a chance of Alan getting hurt or killed, as his legs are no longer strong enough to grip the horse and he has trouble maintaining his balance. At school, Alan overhears a classmate complaining about exercising his pony at lunchtime, and quickly volunteers to do it, despite his father’s warnings. Although his riding is belittled by his school teacher, who tells him to focus on learning, as he is destined for a desk job, Alan continues, and eventually shows his father what he can do.

results.title: I can jump puddles. Ep. 4
results.creator_credit: Kevin Dobson, John Gauci and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: A 9 part television serial about Australian author Alan Marshall, from his childhood and his diagnosis with Polio to his adulthood as he struggles to become a writer. Based on his three autobiographical novels “I can Jump Puddles”, ‘This is the Grass” and “How Beautiful are thy Feet”. Adapting quickly to life with crutches, Alan constantly tries to keep up with the other boys and do all the things that they do. His father’s friend Mr. Radcliff learns of Alan’s ambition to become a writer, he encourages Alan to start keeping a notebook, to note down good stories and yarns, and to constantly experience new things, as all these things will help him to become a great writer. When a family friend invites him to go camping, Alan takes along his notebook and goes along to experience ‘life’.

results.title: Dangerous ground
results.creator_credit: Darrell Roodt, Gillian Gorfil, Ice Cube and New Line Cinema
results.brief_description: After being in exile and living in America for the last 14 years, Vusi Madlazi (Ice Cube) returns to South Africa for his father’s funeral and discovers that South Africa has fallen into the hands of drug baron’s and gang violence. Following his father’s funeral, Vusi’s mother informs him that his brother Steven is missing, feared to be in trouble with one of the major drug baron’s‘s, Muki (Ving Rhames). Along with his girlfriend, Karin (Elizabeth Hurley), Vusi sets out to find his brother in Johannesburg. Together, they discover Stephen has become addicted to crack, owes Muki $45,000 and the debt needs to be paid or else Vusi will end up burying his brother as well.

results.title: Wildside. Eps. 1-2
results.creator_credit: Michael Jenkins, Steve Knapman and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Bill McCoy (Tony Martin) has come back to Sydney after a four year absence, working throughout South East Asia after retiring from the police force due to the level of police corruption and his inability to turn a blind eye. His return is triggered by a phone call from his friend and crisis worker, Syd, that his son Nick is in some kind of trouble. McCoy pays a visit to his ex-wife after having no luck locating Nick, only to be told Nick ended up in a youth detention centre, unbeknownst to Bill - his wife has no idea where their son is. In his venture to locate Nick, Bill meets Dr Maxine Summers (Rachel Blake), who runs a drop in centre for delinquent youth and is treating a young boy named Joe. Joe is a suspect in a ram-raid and car chase that ended with the death of two police officers, while at the same time the body of young boy turns up; tied, raped, tortured and his throat slit.

results.title: Man of marble = Czlowiek z marmuru
results.creator_credit: Andrzej Wajda, Film Polski and Zespol Filmowy 'X'
results.brief_description: Lauded a national hero in the 1950s due to his skills at his trade, Mateusz Birkut has fallen into the shadows. In making a film of the bricklayer’s life, documentary director Krystyna Janda discovers that he used his fame to become involved in politics - resulting in the government wiping out all traces of his accomplishments. Excised by the Polish censors when first released, ‘Man of marble’ uses reconstructions of old black and white newsreels and matches the stylistic tenets of the documentary genre. (Awards: Winner of the FIPRESCI award, Cannes Film Festival, 1978). In Polish with English subtitles.

results.title: The Last seduction
results.creator_credit: John Dahl, Jonathan Shestack and ITC Entertainment Group
results.brief_description: An updated film noir centering around Bridget Gregory, a beautiful, intelligent and ambitious femme fatal. After convincing her doctor husband to pull off a $700,000 cocaine deal, Bridget takes of with the money and hides out in a small town, where she meets Mike. She is tracked down by a private investigator hired by her husband. As the two start to close in on Bridget, she involves Mike in an elaborate scheme to keep the money and get rid of her husband. Cast includes: Linda Fiorentino, Peter Berg, Bill Pullman, J.T. Walsh and Bill Nunn. (Awards: New York)

results.title: Kundun
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Barbara de Fina, Cappa Productions, Refuge Productions and Touchstone Pictures
results.brief_description: Scorsese’s drama detailing the Dalai Lama’s life story was in development for seven years, with the Dalai Lama having input into the 14 screenplay drafts. With four actors portraying the Dalai Lama at different ages, the film begins in 1933 with the death of the 13th Dalai Lama. Born in a remote area, the new Dalai Lama (seen at ages two and five in early sequences) is observed by monks who determine that he is the 14th reincarnation of the Buddha of Compassion. In 1944 he uses newsreels and Western magazines to study WWII events, and as the war ends, he is forced to deal with Chinese Communist aggression. Mao’s military stranglehold on Tibet eventually forces the Dalai Lama to flee to Dharmsala, India. Commenting on the “anti-spiritual…Marxist government of the Chinese Communists,” Scorsese remarked, “What interests me is how a man of non-violence deals with these people - that’s ultimately the story.” With a $28 million budget, he re-created Tibet’s tragedy by filming in south-central Morocco with a cast of nonprofessional Tibetan actors. Second unit work took place at locations in Idaho and British Columbia. Cast includes Tenzin Thuthob Tsarong, Gyurme Ththong, Tencho Gyalpo, Tsewang Migyur Khangsar and Sonam Phunstok.

In 1944 he uses newsreels and Western magazines to study WWII events, and as the war ends, he is forced to deal with Chinese Communist aggression. Mao’s military stranglehold on Tibet eventually forces the Dalai Lama to flee to Dharmsala, India. Commenting on the “anti-spiritual…Marxist government of the Chinese Communists,” Scorsese remarked, “What interests me is how a man of non-violence deals with these people - that’s ultimately the story.” With a $28 million budget, he re-created Tibet’s tragedy by filming in south-central Morocco with a cast of nonprofessional Tibetan actors. Second unit work took place at locations in Idaho and British Columbia. Cast includes Tenzin Thuthob Tsarong, Gyurme Ththong, Tencho Gyalpo, Tsewang Migyur Khangsar and Sonam Phunstok.
